nodes.text: The relative interference of word stimuli and color stimuli in serial verbal reactions differs such that habitual word-reading associations produce stronger interference on color naming than color stimuli produce on word reading, and practice can modify these interference effects

Experimental paradigm: present simultaneous conflicting stimuli by printing color names in ink of a different color so each stimulus contains both a word stimulus and a color stimulus; measure interference as increase in time compared to controls
Experiment 1 measured interference of color stimuli on reading words by comparing time to read 100 color-name words printed in conflicting ink colors (RCNd) versus same words printed in black (RCNb)

Experiment 2 measured interference of word stimuli on naming colors by comparing time to name 100 colors when colors are printed as neutral squares (NC) versus naming the ink-color of printed color words that name a different color (NCWd)

Experiment 3 tested effects of practice: subjects practiced naming ink-colors of conflicting printed words across multiple days to observe change in interference, transfer to other tests, and variability changes

Materials and subjects: five colors used (red, blue, green, brown, purple), balanced arrangements to avoid sequence effects; college student subjects tested individually with timing and error-correction procedures
Operational definitions: interference of color stimuli on reading = RCNd time minus RCNb time; interference of word stimuli on naming colors = NCWd time minus NC time

Result Experiment 1: Reading words printed in conflicting colors took on average 2.3 seconds longer per 100 items (5.6% increase) than reading same words in black; this increase was not statistically reliable

Result Experiment 2: Naming ink-colors of conflicting printed words increased mean time from 63.3 to 110.3 seconds for 100 items (47.0 second increase, 74% increase), a large and reliable interference effect of word stimuli on color naming

Result Experiment 3 (practice on NCWd): Eight days of practice on naming ink-colors of conflicting words produced a 16.8 second (33.9%) reduction on the practiced NCWd test and a 4.0 second (13.9%) improvement on the neutral NC test, but interference remained

Result Experiment 3 (transfer and side effects): Practice on NCWd increased interference of color stimuli on reading (RCNd) causing large loss of speed on RCNd, and the newly developed interference decayed rapidly with a single day of practice on RCNd

Claim: Associations linking word stimuli to the reading response are stronger and more effective than the associations linking color stimuli to the naming response, likely reflecting differential training in reading versus color naming

Claim: Practice selectively modifies interference: sustained practice reduces but does not eliminate strong habitual interference, produces typical learning curves, alters reaction times on related tasks, and changes group variability

Evidence: Quantitative findings support claims â€” small, nonreliable 5.6% RCNd effect vs large 74% NCWd effect; practice gains of 33.9% on NCWd but only 13.9% transfer to NC; RCNd speed loss parallels NCWd gain in absolute units but differs individually

Claim: Practice effects on variability depend on task nature: practice on the difficult, habit-opposed NCWd increased individual variability, while practice reduced variability when practicing the simpler RCNd

Conclusion: The asymmetry in interference (words strongly interfering with color naming but colors weakly interfering with word reading) is attributable to stronger training and habitual association for word reading; practice can reduce but not erase strong habitual interference and can alter mean performance and variability
